It is assumed that fishes used for stomach content analysis were collected by the charter boat sports fishery in the Gulf of Mexico north of Tampa, but specifically around Panama City and Destin, FL. This is the location of the king mackerel fishery from May to October, which is the time period (spring and summer) that the author indicates the stomachs were collected.
Collected at 1971 Texas International Fishing Tournament

GEAR_NOTES: Catch done by sports fisherman and commercial fisherman
Seine Net is 16,000 meshes long and 1,000 meshes wide.  Completed, the net is 1,125 ft (342.9 m) long and 85 ft (25.908 m) deep

stomach-content analysis were performed using drum that were caught by local fishermen and those turned in at rodeos along the Mississippi Gulf coast.

3 boats used - 16ft airdrive powered by a 250hp Lycoming aircraft engine for extremely shallow areas, 16ft fiberglass boat powered by a 60hp outboard motor for deeper areas, 16ft flat-bottom skiff powered by 50hp outboard motor.  5000 ft of gill nets ranged  in length between 100 and 300 feet with mesh sizes of 4, 5, and 7 inch stretch.

FIELD_PRES_NOTES: Stomaches were preserved for later identification

GEAR_NOTES: Because of size selectivity of the trammel net (fish 6.0 inches or larger in length), additional sampling of smaller fish and crustaceans were collected by a 16' otter trawl and a 6' bobbinet were used.
FIELD_PRES_NOTES: Stomaches were preserved for later identification

GEAR_NOTES: 20 foot, 60 foot and 100 foot bag seine

Fishes were collected from the Clear Lake area and its tributaries with a 3m otter  trawl. A 6mm bar mesh cover was used over the cod end or the trawl during some of the sampling to capture post larval fish, many of which were less than 15mm in length. The larger bar of mesh of the trawl  19mm and 13 mm in the body and length . The larger bar of mesh of trawl, 19 mm and 13mm in the body and cod end, respectively, permitted many of the smaller fish to escape when the cover was not used.
